div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THURSDAY, APRIL 25, 1907.

div.head: THE EGYPTIANS AND LORD COMER.
div.p: The date for Lord Cromer's departure from Egypt is now fixed for May 6. In less than a fortnight's time the land to which he has given the best years of his life will know him no more. But, though there must be an element of sadness in such parting, the general tribute of admiration and respect which he will carry away with him can hardly fail to fill his mind with deep satisfaction. It is much, says the " Times " to have earned the, gratitude of his own countrymen for the great things which he has done in their name. It is much to have won the frank and generous praise of other nations, some of whom have been strongly opposed in the past to certain features in the policy which he pursued, but who now recognize with one accord that the great English statesman and administrator has deserved well of civilization. But we fancy that even more grateful to his ears than the commendations of either must be the cry of regret at his departure which goes up from the people he has so long helped, to rule. The European Press acknowledges the greatness of the man and of his services without reserve. The native organs, including some of the more moderate advocates of a Nationalist policy, pay homage to his statesmanship, to his zeal for progress, and to his devotion to the interests of Egypt. Down to the peasants of distant provinces and to the poor in the streets of the capital, all classes of the Egyptian people, without distinction of creed or of race, are expressing their grief at his resignation and their thanks for his labours in the cause of their country. Whilst the Khedive in the course of a farewell audience expressed to him his regret, many members of the Khedivial family, of the Legislative Council, and of the General Assembly, the Ministers, the chief officials, the Patriarchs and Bishops of the Christian Churches, the dignitaries of the Jewish and Moslem communities, the principal Judges of the Mixed and Native Tribunals, Turkish and Egyptian Pashas, and Sheikhs of the Bedouin tribes have gone to the British agency to do honour to the "father and regenerator of Egypt," as a Coptic journal calls him. Not less significant is the grief with which the news of his departure is received in the provinces. The local rulers of the people openly lament the loss which is about to be fall them, and it is instructive to learn that the older men, who can remember the abuses of the old regime, which Lord Cromer has done so much to abolish, are loudest in their regrets. No class in Egypt has derived greater or more palpable benefits from his administration than he peasant cultivators of the soil. They are lot ungrateful, and many letters, we are assured, have reached him which bear touching witness to their feelings. No testimony to his services can be more acceptable, we are conident, to a ruler such as he.

That Mustapha Kamel Pasha should seize his occasion to indulge in a bitter and mendacious attack upon the man whom all the world is praising, and that Abdul Hamid's representative in Egypt should bear witness to the high character of Lord Cromer's tradcer, is natural and intelligible. The charge which the editor of "El Lewa" brings against the statesman who has created modern Egypt ire a measure of his sincerity and intelligence. Whatever credence such accusations may find amongst the ignorant and fanatical clique to which they are addressed, they are too palpably false to command belief amongst educated men of any nationality or of any political opinions. To say that Lord Cromer has deprived the poor of education and that he has attacked the Moslem faith may gratify Mukhtar, who, as the Sultan's representative, is as authoritative a champion of freedom ant! Parliamentary institutions as Mustapha Kamel. The blessing which the Turkish Pasha bestows onthe Egyptian "patriot" is, however, perhaps less likely to strengthen than to weaken whatever inclination sentimental politicians in European countries may have felt to sympathize with Egyptian "Nationalism" as Mustapha Kamel and Mukhtar understand and expound it. Lord Cromer has taken the measure of the movement and has explained it to his countrymen. It is natural that the champions of the agitation should resent its exposure.

div.head: Daman hour Moudirieh.
div.p: The contract for the construction of a new building and annexes for the Damanhour moudirieh has been adjudicated in favour of Messrs. Yosmadellis and Perini.

div.head: Creek Tourists
div.p: The members of the Greek tourist club of Athens, Omilos tou Ekdromon are expected to arrive at Alexandria early next month and after spending two days here they will leave for Cairo.

div.head: The Grandmoulin Affair
div.p: Mr. Grandmoulin intends to bring an action for libel against the proprietor of the "Egyptian Standard'' for the disgraceful allegation of murdering a native boy at Warrak, which that paper published against him.

div.head: The Dugay-Trouin.
div.p: The commander of the French training ship for cadets Dugay-Trouin paid an official visit yesterday to Mr. Pierre Girard, French Diplomatic Agent, who returned the visit on board the Dugay-Trouin in the afternoon.

div.head: The Holy Carpet
div.p: The contract for the supply of silver and gold threads for the Holy Carpet has been given to Said Abdel Khalik Ahmed, a Cairo merchant, whose estimate was 40 milliemes per mitkal of gold and 28 milliemes per mitkal of silver.

div.head: The National Bank
div.p: The new headquarters at Alexandria of the National Bank of Egypt in Toussoun-street will occupy an area of twelve hundred square metres. The building is to be two stories with a fine central hall. The style of architecture is classical Renaissance.

div.head: Sharakl Lands
div.p: A decree has been issued by the Ministry of Public Works prohibiting from the 15th of May and until further notice the watering of Sharaki lands in Lower and Middle Egypt, with the exception of those reserved for the cultivation of rice, vegetables, and like cultures.

div.head: The Swiss in Egypt.
div.p: Two Swiss papers refer to the creation of a Swiss General Consulate in Alexandria The Consul General in Cairo is also to have the attribute of a Diplomatic Agent. The creation of both Consulates is thought to be necessary in consideration of the considerable traffic between Switzerland and Egypt. At present the Swiss are under the French or German Consulates.

div.head: The Russian Affair
div.p: The Procureur General of Trieste has issued what is known as an "Ordonnance de non lieu" in the case of Mr. Alfred Campos's connection with the recent Anti-Russian manifestation at Alexandria. Another question arising out of the same affair was dealt with this morning at the Italian Consular Court at Alexandria when the libel actions brought by Mr. Herzenstein were pleaded. The defendants are the persons who signed a pamphlet which was published during the excitement.

div.head: New Victoria Hotel.
div.p: Amongst the latest arrivals at the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh, are Mr. and Mrs. Pittner, the Misses Pittner, Count Tattenbach, Dr. and Mrs. Crane, Mr. James Carrol Willcocks, Mrs. A. Jucopoulo, Miss M. Tocoponlo, the Misses Taropoulo, Miss M. Fish Mr. R S. Milward, Mr. Mohamed Bey Fouad and. family, Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Sehitz, Mr. F. W. Skeates, Mr. E. A. Gray, Miss Gray, Mrs. Vivian, Vernon, Miss Vernon, Mr. George Mellab and family, Miss F. Dahn, Miss R. Frutiger, Mr. Mahmut Bey Rifaat, Miss A. P. Pinnegar.

div.head: A Succesful Company.
div.p: The directors of Babcock and Wilcox who are represented in Egypt by the British Engineering Company of Alexandria have declared a dividend of 2s. 4 4 5d. per share (including bonus), free of income tax, making with interim dividend, a total dividend of 16 per cent, and a bonus of 4 per cent, for the year 1906. Since its re registration in 1900 this remarkably successful company of water- tube steam boiler manufacturers has rapidly progressed. For 1900 the ordinary shares in the new company received 12 1/2 per cent. ; for 1901, 15 ; for 1902 and 1903, 17 ; and for 1904, 20 ; while in June, 1905, a bonus of 50 per cent, was paid in ordinary shares out of the reserve fund.

div.head: Red Tape
div.p: An amusing instance of official red-tape is mentioned by Lord Cromer in his Report. He remarks: I have on tormer occasions frequently alluded to the tendency which exists amongst officials in Egypt to multiply correspondence unnecessarily. I have now before me a typical instance of the abuse to which I allude It consists of an official file of thirty-one pages, all typewritten. The first paper is dated the 26th February, 1905, and is the translation of an Arabic deed, from which it appears that "the wise man Mohamed Osman Ali-el Zaker, from Benyan, Assouan Province, bought from his nephew, Mohamed Ali-Zaker, from the same village and province, half of a donkey for the sum of 195 Tuakish piastres." It seems that a doubt arose as to whether the donkey had been bought or stolen. On this subject, 73 official notes are recorded by various officials, residing at Assouan, Dongola, Cairo, and elsewhere. The last of these notes is dated the 11th November, 1906, and the question of the ownership of the donkey, although it had been under discussion for one year and nine months, was apparently, still unsettled. I greatly hope that heads of Departments will do all in their power to check proceedings of this description.

div.head: THE CAIRO DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: The manifestation of Lord Cromer will take place in the Khedivial Opera House at 6 p.m. on Saturday, May 4, when Count de Serionne will make a speech on behalf of the European colonies, to which Lord Cromer will reply in French. Mustapha Pasha Fahmy will also speak in the name of the country and Lord Cromer will reply by a long political discourse.

div.head: TESTIMONIES FROM THE SUDAN.
div.p: The Greek community of Khartoum Rave sent the following telegram to Lord Cromer through their President, Mr. Angelo Capato:—

As President of the Greek community at Khartoum and on behalf of the Greeks throughout the Anglo Egyptian Sudan. I beg to express the regret with which we hear of your Lordship's illness and retirement, to thank you for all you have done for us in the past, and to offer our hopes for the early return of your Lordship's health. It is almost impossible to imagine that your unexpected retirement will not retard this country's progress, and we can only trust that your successor will continue to proceed upon the path so clearly and well marked by you in the past. We trust your Lordship will accept this expression of the feeling of the Greek community of this vast territory as a true and heartfelt one.
Lord Cromer replied as follows :—

I beg you to accept and to communicate to the Members of the Hellenic Community in the Sudan the expression of my sincerest thanks for the telegram 1 have just received. I trust that the members of that community whose valuable services and spirit of enterprise I have had so many occasions to recognise will continue to flourish in health and prosperity.
A similar telegram was sent to his Lordship by Shahin Bey George, president of the Syrian community in Khartoum.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst arrived here this morning by the Brindisi mail steamer Osiris at 5.30 a in. No officials boarded the Osiris till 7 a.in. when Mr. D A. Cameron, C B., H.B.M's Consul and the Governor arrived. The party left the steamer about half past seven for the Customs House stage, where they were met by other officials, including Dixon Bey,. Schalch Bey, Mr. Dumont, Principal Agent of the Suez Canal Co., and Mr Tarell, Director of Customs. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst drove direct to the station and left immediately for Cairo by the special train, which was awaiting them.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT CAIRO.
div.p: Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst arrived at Cairo at 12.10 p.m. and were met at the station by Lewa Watson Pasha, representing the Khedive, Lady Cromer, Moustafa Pasha Fahmy, Mr. A. D. Alban, Mahmoud Sidki Pasha, Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, Mansfield Pasha, Bernard Pasha, Crookshank Pasha, Mr Trevithick, and others. The train by which Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst arrived was drawn by a new engine which has been named "Lady Cromer."

div.head: PREMATURE NEWS.
div.p: The English portion of our Cairo contemporary "L'Orient," in its issue this morning, reports the meeting of the British Colony which is to be held to-morrow. Such premature reporting is unexampled, we should think, even in the case of American journalism. Here is the paragraph "from the paper to which we refer :—
"As already announced the British Colony at Alexandria met yesterday to express regrets at the departure of Lord Cromer.
"A telegram expressing this was sent to Lord Cromer, and he was asked to pass through Alexandria when leaving Egypt that the British Colony 'might make a demonstration in his honour."

div.head: SUDAN GAME HUNTING.
div.p: Mr. Luigi Beretta, of Milan, who .is well- known in big game hunting circles in Europe has just returned from a hunt in the Sudan. In spite of the excessive heat, Mr. Beretta succeeded in obtaining a plentiful bag, including a fine specimen of the African bison, the horns of which measured 34 inches from tip to tip. Mr. Beretta was accompanied by the renowned naturalist Dr. David, who rendered valuable services in the scientific exploration of the trip. All the arrangements were carried out by the Cairo-Office of the Hamburg American Line under the super per vision of the Manager, Mr. D.E. Munari.

The full returns of animals killed during the past year are not yet complete, but it is believed that the number will tie about the same as in 1905—that is to say, 2,160. Game in the sanctuary has been as little disturbed as possible. Very few' animals were killed in it by the officials stationed within its boundaries. The officers' reserve has been less shot than in 1905. 105 head of game were killed in it, against 153 in the preceding year. The game laws have been observed in a most satisfactory manner during the year. There have been no serious cases of infringement. The confiscation of the tusks of six cow elephants shot during the year, and of the tusks of an undersized bull, was the only action taken under the Ordinance.

div.head: THE PUBLIC WORKS CASE
ELEVEN LIBEL ACTIONS.
div.p: Mr. C. H. Moore, of the Second Circle of Irrigation, is bringing actions for libel against eight local newspapers. These journals are "The Egyptian Standard," "Al Lewa, " "L'Etenard Egyptien," "Al Ahram," "Les Pyramides," "Al Minbar," "Al Moayad," and the "Journal du Caire." He is also bringing actions for libel against Dervish Effendi Mustapha, a native advocate of Cairo, and in all probability against Aly Bey Ghazzal, a large landed proprietor of the. Menoufieh. Province, and Mahmoud Bey Abdul Ghaffir a notable of Menoufieh.

The judgment pronounced by the Native Court of the Mousky in the case of Serghani, head Arabic clerk to Mr. Moore, arose should be remembered, from the charges brought against Mr. Moore. The sentence of a year's hard labour passed by the Court on Sirghani completely exculpates Mr. Moore from the vindictive accusations brought against him. The Parquet, considering that Serghani's punishment is inadequate, have decided to appeal.
Mr. Moore's action for libel will come before the Mixed Courts about the end of next month.
He will be represented by Maltre Carton de Wiart. The Egyptian Government fully concur in the proceedings which Mr. Moore is taking.

div.head: CAIRO LAND VALUES.
div.p: In our issue of the 23rd inst. regarding the sale of the Standard Life Building, in Cairo, at L.E. 58 per metre, we are informed that the price should be L.E 58 J per metre We also stated that this was the highest price realised to date for any property in .Cairo. On further enquiry, however, we find that this is not so, as several properties have changed hands at much higher prices. In the Kasr-el-Nil street, some months ago, the National Bank pajd LE. 60 per metre for a piece of land with a very small frontage on the street ; and for a comer piece almost 'opposite, in the same street, L.E. 75 per metre was refused. In the same street again, on a piece of land with no frontage, owned by three partners, two of the partners bought out the interest of the -third at L E. 6 per metre.

In the Mousky quarter, even higher prices than these have been paid. Over a year ago a fair sized property»changed hands in the Mousky at L E 65 per metre, and the present proprietor is obtaining 12$% on his money at that price. The Wakfs Administration refused L E. 100 per metre for land just outside the Mousky, and several similar properties have changed hands at prices ranging from LE 80 to L E 90 per metre.

It is true that buyers for suburban land outside Cairo are not so plentiful as they were, but for anything in the way of choice sites in the main streets of Cairo buyers are plentiful and the prices continue to rise, and in the opinion of experts will continue do so until L E 100 per metre is reached, that is to say if there are good frontages.

div.head: SUDAN TELEGRAPHS. EXTENSION SOUTHWARDS.
div.p: When the late Mr. Cecil Rhodes was in Cairo some few years ago, he spoke to Lord Cromer on the subject of establishing direct telegraphic communication between the north and the south of Africa. So far as the Egyptian and Sudanese portion of this work is concerned, the execution of the idea is within a measurable distance of completion. Telegraphic communication has for some while existed between Khartoum and Tewfikieh, which is situated at the junction of the Sobat and White Nile. Owing to the vast extent of marsh which exists between Tewfikieh and the Bahr- el-Ghazal Province, it was decided not to extend the line from the terminus at Tewfikieh to Meshra-er-Rek, but to facilitate rapid communication by means of small oil-launches. A weekly service was instituted between these two places early in January 1906. In the winter of 1904-05, a telegraph line was constructed from Meshra-er-Rek to Waw, and thence to Tonj. This line was subsequently extended to Rumbek, a distance of 80 miles, where a telegraph station was opened on the 15th April, 1906. A tract was then out to Mvolo (60 miles), a reconnaissance of the country between Bor and Mvolo was made by Major Turner, R.E, and the line to the latter place is now in course of construction. On it* completion, Khartoum will be in communication with Uganda by telegraph to Tewfikieh, thence by telegraph launches to Meshra-er-Rek, and from the latter place by telegraph to Gonriokoro. The question now presents itself of how to fill up the difficult gap south of Tewfikieh. After full consideration, and an examination of the country, it has been decided to carry the telegraph line 100 miles along the east bank of the Bahr el Zeraf, and thence across the Iwi country to Bor. A line already exist from Bahr to Gondokoro. It was opened on the 19th April, 1906. Thus, before long there will be direct telegraphic communication from Alexandria to the centre of Africa.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
NEW MANAGEMENT. 29242-26-11-90

div.head:
THE OCCUPATION OE EGYPT.
A SECRET HISTORY
div.p: Mr. Fisher Unwin has arranged to bring out shortly a work -which has long been promised, and is likely just now to attract considerable attention, entitled The Secret History of the English Occupation of Egypt: a Personal Memoir of Events, by Mr. Wilfrid Blunt It purports to perform a. double historic Junction : first, .that of giving: an: account— -more accurate than has yet been attempted and derived from confidential native sources— of the National Egyptian movement of the years' 188L-2 ,and secondly,-that of revealing the, political and financial intrigues which in Europe led to the intervention of England and the prolonged military occupation of the Nile Valley. Its chief interest will lie in the candour of the recital, and the revelation of the writer's own doings in Egypt and in Downing Street. It may indeed be said to be Mr. Blunt's, apologia in regard both: to past events and to his present attitude towards the Egyptian question.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, has returned to Cairo from Ismailia. Yesterday morning his Highness received Mr. Mahmusi. the newly appointed Italian Diplomatic Agent, at Abdeen Palace, when the latter presented his credentials. His Highness also received Herz Bey who presented a copy of his latest work. Fathy Pasha Zagloul, Ahmed Pasha Afifi, Yehia Pasha Ibrahim, Nousret Bey, Miralai Matchett Bey, and Count 'Bernstorff, who presented Lieutenant Beyersdorff and Dr. Schaefer. It is said that his Highness, after visiting-Matarieh, will proceed to Port Said where he will embark on board the Mahroussa for Alexandria Last night his Highness was present at the official closing ceremony of the Mouled el Nebi at Abbassieh, and assisted at the oration of Said el Bakri on the life of the prophet.

div.head: CAIRO LAND BRICKS CO. LTD.
div.p: On page 4 we publish the prospectus of the Cairo Land Bricks Company Limited, the subscription of-which will be opened (text Friday at 10 am. at the Bank of Salonica at Cairo and Alexandria, and will be closed at midday . on Saturday. This issue is really made to conform with the law and regulations of the Bourse, the promoters having a full guarantee of the issue. They desire, however, to give the public the chance of participation in the business which starts under the best possible auspices. Among those guaranteeing the issue are Joseph Bey Cataoui-Aslan, Mr F. M. Singer, manager of the Bank of Salonica, Mr. Jacot des Combes, Mr. Bachler, George Nungovich Bey, Mr. Rolin, etc...

div.head: EGYPT'S MINING INDUSTRY.
div.p: The general conclusion of Mr. J. M. Wills, the Inspector General of Mines in his report on the mining industry, is as follows : —

"The data collected during the year confirm the opinion expressed in my last report, that there is every prospect of developing a mineral industry From 125 miles south of Cairo down to the Sudan border, there are many old mines awaiting development. The prospecting of the country cannot begin until it is open to prospectors, and time must be allowed for preliminary exploration and development Egypt as a mining country is still under a cloud. The deserts have hardly had any attention paid to them. a* yet, and the amount of prospecting that has been done is infinitesimal."

div.head:
A.S.C.
LAWN TENNIS TOURNAMENT.
div.p: Owing to pressure on our space we are obliged to hold over until to-morrow the publication of the result of the draw of the open Lawn Tennis Tournament.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman S.S City of Khios arrived from Jaffa yesterday evening, and will load for Liverpool.
The S.S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday morning.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The King of Siam during his stay at Port Said bought a quantity of tarboushes for himself and his suite.

The Sirdar will probably leave Khartoum on the 1st of May for Port Sudan and Erkwit where he will spend a part of that month. Sir R. Baron von Slatin Pasha will accompany him to Port Sudan, whence he will go by sea to Egypt and, after spending a few days in Cairo, will proceed on; leave to Europe for the summer.

Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, will undertake his trip to Marioutin the course of next week. Be had already started on his journey when he had to return to Cairo in consequence of the cab-strike.

The English, portion of "L'Orient" announces that' Prince Mohamed Ali has arrived at Alexandria and will-embark on May 1 for a long sea voyage. His Highness is still at Constantinople, and the date of his departure is unfixed.
The Finance Ministry has given LE. £600 to Mrs. Verschoyle the widow of the late Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt.
Fathy Zaghloul Pasha, Under Secretary of State, at the Ministry of Justice, has been appointed a member of the Committee of Judicial Superintendence

The "Guardian" bf April 17th announces that the Rev. R.F. Rynd M:A. late Assistant Chaplain of St. Mark's, Alexandria, and All Saint's, Ramleh, has been appointed Precentor and Minor Canon of Norwich Cathedral.
Mr. Theotokis, the brother of the Greek Prime Minister, who has been staying for Home time at Ramleh, left Alexandria yesterday for Corfou.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place in August, between Mr. H.T R. Dray, of the Egyptian Civil Service, and Miss Margaret Eleanor Mills, eldest daughter of the Rev. Cecil Mills, of Bisterue and Tayerham.

A marriage has been arranged and will take place on Monday next, the 29th inst., between Mulazin Awal Walter Tyrrell, of the Alexandria City Police, and Miss Parkinson, the sister of Mr. H.F.C. Parkinson, Manager of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company Limited. The marriage will take place at the British Consulate and subsequently at All Saints' Church, Ramleh. Mr. and Mrs. Tyrrell will spend their honeymoon at Cairo.

div.head: DISGRACEFUL BEHAVIOUR.
div.p: Under this heading-the English portion of "L'Orient" published yesterday a disquieting paragraph for which, it appears, there was not the slightest foundation, as the same paper has been 'obliged to state in to-day's paper. Such statements are most regrettable. The following is the paragraph referred to

We understand that as the funeral procession of Private Netherway of the Coldstream Guards neared the cemetery on Sunday lost, several natives created a disturbance and hurled stones at the funeral party. The civil police; owing to some misunderstanding were late in arrival and so did not accompany the funeral. This disgraceful scene is in itself an answer to those who say, that all they advocate is peaceful opposition and that fanaticism is not their object

div.head: SUDAN RUBBER.
div.p: Experiments arebeing conducted in the growing of rubber vines, Landolphia Owariensis," at Wau. Rubber produced from these vines and treated with citric acid has been submitted to brokers, whose opinions show that it is as good as any rubber on the market It has not yet been definitely proved that the Para rubber tree, which produces the best known rubber, will grow in the Soudan. As is well known, this tree is being planted to a huge extent in various parts of the world, and in a few years' time a very large increase in the output of Para rubber is expected. The consequence of this would be to flood, inferior rubber out of the market. The result of the examination of the above, mentioned samples tends to show that no fears need« be entertained for Soudan rubber in that event, provided the rubber is properly prepared. It stiff remains to be shown, however, what productivity may be expected from Landolphia vines, and how long it will take them to reach the bearing stage. Recent explorations show that the Bahr-el-Ghazal Province contains more rubber vines than was at one time believed.

The profits of the Company made during the financial Year or other period comprised in the Accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year with any profits' carried forward from past years shall be applicable in order of priority and manner following: — 1. Five per cert of such profits shall be carried to a Reserve Fund but so that whenever such Reserve Fund shall amount to fifty per cent of the paid up Capital of the Company this provision shall cease to apply.
2 The balance shall be applied to the payment of a non-cumulative preferential Dividend for such period at the rate of six per cent per annum on the Capital paid up on the Ordinary' Shares.

3. Of the surplus ten per cent shall he said to the Directors as remuneration for their services 60 per cent shall be applicable to the payment of a further dividend on the Capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares or may be carried to Reserve or otherwise dealt with as the Company in General Meeting determines and 30 per cent shall be divided rateably among the Holders of the Founders Shares.
In case of a winding up any surplus assets after repayment of Capital shall be divided as to 60 per cent among the the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the number held
and as to 40 per cent among the Holders of the Founders Shares rateably.

PROSPECTUS.
The Company has been formed for the objects mentioned in its Memorandum of Association and more especially for the purchase and development and extension of the Abbassia Sand Bricks Company G m.b H.

The Abbassia Sand Brick Company G. m; b. H. (hereinafter called the Old Company) was started about two years ago to meet the increasing demand in Cairo and its suburbs for bricks and building materials. A factory was set up by the Old Company and the main work of this factory was the manufacture of sand-bricks.

These bricks are made of a mixture of sand and lime (both of which materials are found in abundance in close proximity to the factory) and possess many excellent building qualities. They are more durable and offer a greater power of resistance than the ordinary clay brick and at the same time they can be turned out ready for immediate use in a far shorter space of time.

These advantages are naturally appreciated by building and construction firms and companies and large contracts have already been fulfilled for some of the most important of these in Cairo and its suburbs

The Semiramis Hotel is built of sand bricks furnished by the Old Company, and a contract has already been entered into for supplying sand-bricks for the new Ritz Hotel that is shortly to be erected at Garden City, Kasr-el-Aine, Cairo. Orders have also been received from the Heliopolis Oasis Company, from the contractor for the new barracks at Abbassia and other important building and contracting firms.
In short so many orders have been taken and so many demands have been-made on the Old Company that it has been found impossible to fulfil them all with the present factory.

It has been decided therefore to form toe Cairo Sand Bricks Company Limited (hereinafter called the New Company) to take overall assets and liabilities of the Old Company as from the 31st day of December 1906 and with the increased capital that will be provided to considerably enlarge the factory already in existence
In this way it is hoped that the output will be more than doubled and that substantial profits will consequently accrue to the New Company.

The purchase price to be paid for the business and goodwill of the Old Company has been fixed at Lst, 45.000. This sum will be satisfied by the allotment of fully paid Ordinary and Founders Shares of the New Company as is shown by Agreement No. 1 set out hereunder. For this price the new Company will acquire some &5O0 square metres of land at Abbassia and the plant, machinery, fixtures, etc. of the old Company. Further it will take over the benefit of all contracts entered into by the Old Company in the ordinary course of its business as well as all its liabilities subsequent to the 31st December 1906.

The situation of the site of the factory is in the Directors' opinion in every way an excellent one. The necessary material for the manufacture of the bricks is close at hand and in the matter of transport the factory possesses exceptional facilities having at its doors a secondary line of the State Railways and a Branch line of the Delta Light Railways Company. Further lying as it does between Cairo and the Heliopolis Oasis delivery by road to either of these important building centres can be easily effected.
The Vendors to and the promoters of the New Company are the Old Company and the following contract has been entered into by them with the New Company.

N° 1. AGREEMENT dated the 10th day of April 1907 and made between the Old Company whose registered office is situated at Alexandria of the one part and the New Company of the other part whereby the New Company have the right to acquire from the Old Company as from the 1st day of January 1907 subject to the liabilities of the Old Company subsequent to that date its land and buildings at Abbassia and all its plant stock machinery implement materials and good-will for the sum of Lst. 45,000 to be satisfied by the allotment to the Old Company of 44,250 Ordinary Shares of Lst. 1 each and 15.000 Founders Shares of One Shilling each of the New Company all credited as fully paid. Of this amount no sum is payable for goodwill.

div.head: The Articles of Association contain the following provsions :
div.p: Art. 85. — The qualification of a Director shall be the holding of Ordinary Shares of the Company to the nominal value of Lst. '200.

Art. 86. — As remuneration for their services each Director shall be paid a fixed salary at the rate of Lst 50 per annum. And the Directors shall also be paid collectively the share of surplus profits mentioned in Art 120 (being the 10% hereinbefore referred to) and such remuneration shall be divided among them in such proportions and manner as they may determine and in default of such determination equally.
Art. 99. — The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be a Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company.

Art 102. — The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits or by any or all of those modes. A Managing Director shall unless otherwise determined be entitled to remuneration as a Director.

Art. 111. — If any of the Directors shall be called upon to perform extra services or to travel or reside in any part of the world for any of the purposes of the Company or the business thereof the Company shall remunerate the Director or Directors so doing in such manner as may be determined by the Directors and such remuneration may ^ be either in addition to or in substitution for his or their share in the remuneration hereinbefore provided for the Directors.
The Minimum Subscription on which the Directors may proceed to Allotment is fixed by the Articles of Association at 25 per cent of the shares offered for subscription.

As before mentioned Mr. Frederick Maurice Singer has in the Memorandum of Association guaranteed the subscription of 54.500 Ordinary Shares and he has formed a Syndicate of Guarantee who by the terms of an Agreement dated 2nd April 1907 (herein referred to as agreement N° 2) have agreed to take firm 19.500 Ordinary Shares and to guarantee the subscription by the public of 35.000 Ordinary Shares. For this the members of the said Syndicate of Guarantee will be entitled to call for and receive a transfer from Mr. F.M. Singer at par of the respective numbers of Founders Shares set out in the said agreement opposite to their respective names
Other than this no commission will be paid by the Company for underwriting.
The preliminary expenses Are estimated at list 1.000 and will be paid by the Company.

Copies of the above mentioned agreements together with a print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company (a copy of which Memorandum is printed on the back of this prospectus and forms part thereof) may be seen at the Banque de Salonique at any time during business hours before the list of subscription is closed.
Of the Directors the following are interested in the formation of the Company.
Mr. Paul Hahnloser has a five twefths and Mr. Albert Baechler a seven seventy fifths interest in the profits of the Old Company.

The following Directors are members of the Syndicate of Guarantee above mentioned. They will take firm the number of the Ordinary Shares set out in the first column hereunder opposite their respective names and will guarantee the subscription by the public of the number of Ordinary Shares set out in the second column hereunder opposite their respective names. For this they will receive a transfer at par from Mr. F.M. Singer of the number of Founders Shares set out in the third column hereunder opposite their respective names while Mr. F.M. Singer will retain the number of Founders shares set opposite his name.

Application for Shares should be made on accompanying forms and torwarded with a cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no Allotment is made the application money will be returned in full and wire the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the applicants.
Failure to pay any instalments when due will render the previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Copies of this Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the Banque de Salonique at Cairo and Alexandria.
Dated 22nd April 1907;

div.head: TURKISH CUSTOMS DUTIES. Violation of regulations. BRITISH AMBASSADOR'S FIRMNESS

div.p: When the Ambassadors assembled on 22nd inst. to sign the final agreement increasing the Customs' duties, Sir N. O'Conor regretted that he was unable to sign the document as certain customs regulations were being flagrantly violated. Sir N. O'Conor's firmness is generally approved. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COLONIAL CONFERENCE. MR. HALDANE'S ADDRESS.

div.p: In his address at the Colonial Conference on the subject of Imperial defence, Mr. Haldane advocated the exchange of Imperial and Colonial officers and advised the Colonies to order their arms and ammunition through the War Office, thus to secure uniformity, and to send their experts to the War Office to confer with the general staff
General Botha urged an immediate federation of South Africa for its defence if, at present, a political federation was. impossible.
(Renter)

It is understood that General Botha proposed at the Conference the establishment of a general South African defence force, with a view to maintaining in various states a force sufficiently strong to deal with any internal trouble.
(Reuter)

div.head: POLITICAL PRISONERS IN RIGA. TORTURED BEFORE EXECUTION.

div.p: A sensation was caused in the Duma yesterday by the reading of the report of a commission, the truth of which is admitted by Government officials, showing that political prisoners in Riga have been subjected to horrible tortures prior to their execution, in order to endeavour to extort confessions : their toenails were extracted, they were beaten with india-rubber flails, and their bones were broken by compression. The Government has announced that it has ordered an enquiry and the prosecution of the guilty. (Router)
The arsenal fire has destroyed five buildings. The damages are estimated at nine millions. The number of injured is forty, five of which are dying.
The fire broke out in five places simultaneously. This fact revives the rumours of foul play in the case of the Jena. (Reuter)
The Tsar in his interview with M. Golovine expressed his confidence that the Duma would work in agreement with the Government. (H.)
The existence of plague at Cartagena is denied. (Havas)
The Chamber of Deputies has approved the international contention relating to hospital ships. (Havas)

div.head: MR. HALDANE'S ARMY BILL. COLONIAL PREMIERS' APPROVAL.

div.p: House of Commons. Mr. Haldane's territorial army bill has been read for the second time and passed by 343 votes to 31.

Mr. Haldane mentioned that the Colonial Premiers unanimously agreed that his proposed territorial force was the best pattern which they could keep in view in organising their home forces ; there would thus be a chain of territorial forces in the Empire which might afford a real sense of security. The Government regarded the bill as a bulwark against conscription. (Reuter)
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught have arrived. (Reuter)
The Canadian Pacific Railway is just keeping the passenger traffic moving with imported American coal. (Reuter)
The lemonade boys and the bakers have decided to continue the strike. (Havas)

City and Suburban Handicap (Epsom). I. Velocity ; 2. Larino ; 3 Succour. 13 ran. Won by 3 lengths. A length and a half dividing the second and third. Starting price betting : 6 to 1 Velocity ; 3 to 1 Larino ; 100 to 7 Succour.(Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET-
div.p: The Money Market.

Notwithstanding the fact that the new London County Council loan and one or two other issues of lesser importance have, been placed this week, there still continues to be a plethora of -money in Lombard Street, and there are no signs that the present condition of ease is likely to reach a limit for some considerable time to come.

There has been a great rush for the County Council loan; and it is stated that the portion offered to the public, amounting to £2,500,000, was covered between twenty and thirty times. It is understood that applicants for large amounts will have to be content with about 8 per cent, of the amount asked for. The new issue is quoted on the Stock Exchange at about 1/2 premium.

The Budget proposals of the Chancellor of the Exchequer are looked upon very favourably from the money market point of view. Mr. Asquith in his speech very properly pointed out that there had been enormous additions to capital liabilities of the state and municipalities ; the admission of Colonial stocks into the category of trustee investments ; abnormal activity in trade, leading to higher prices and higher wages, as well as other causes which had contributed to the fall in gilt-edged securities. He also gave a not unnecessary reminder that per cent, stock at S3, a point it had not yet reached—was equal to 3 percent, stock at par. Even with the fluctuations which have taken place, our credit still stands higher than that of any other country.

The Bank return this week shows a further addition to the reserve of £659,000, and the proportion to liabilities has improved 1$ to -14 J per cent. There is an increase of £438,000 in the stock of bullion, while the note circulation shows a contraction of £221,000. The market has reduced its indebtedness to the Bank by £639,000.
Silver.
Although the price of silver is not very firm at present, it is believed that a further rise will shortly take place. Yesterday the question improved to 30. 15/16d. per ounce.
The Stock Markets.

Paucity of business continues to be the general complaint of members of the Stock Exchange, and this highly respectable fraternity are more and more convinced that they are hardly used by the investing public. They recollect with sorrow of heart the days when membership of the "House" was a thing to live for, and it is little comfort to them to be told that they largely owe their present unhappy condition to the marvellous prosperity of the trade of the country. Yet, as we have before pointed out this is an undeniable fact. The investing public have been so badly bitten by the decreasing values of stocks and shares, that nowadays if they are able to pat out their money to fair interest in a good industrial concern, they are content to leave the Stock Exchange severely alone.

This week markets have been very inactive, and for the most part the tone has been weak. The Budget announcement, while it has created & favourable impression, has entirely failed to stimulate business, and stagnation prevails almost throughout.
Console.

The gilt-edged section continues to display a weak tone, and Consols have shown a drooping tendency. To-day they opened a trifle higher, but have since fallen away, and close 1/4 lower for cash and account at 85 13/16and 85 15/16| respectively.
Foreign Bonds.

After being firm and well supported, the market for international bonds was inclined to be dull yesterday. Russian securities, which had been previously favoured, shed 1/4, the Fours closing tit 75 and the last issue at 85 1/4, at which prices they showed advances on our last quotations of 1/2 and 3/4 respectively.
Japanese have been quiet and steady. There was some demand for the Four-and-a-half per cents., and the price was put up 1/4 to 95. Yesterday, however, the stock lost the advance, closing at 94 3/4.
Foreign Government bonds have been neglected to-day, but quotations are generally maintained. Russians and Japanese are unaltered.
Home Ralls,

On Monday home rails were a very good market, and in most cases substantial advances on last week's prices were marked at the close. The public interest has not however, been maintained, and during the rest of the week the tone has been dull, with the exception of two or three stocks, notably Central London and the Scottish Preference. Central London were very active at the beginning, and both Ordinary and Deferred improved 3 and 2 respectively. These shares have continued firm throughout, the Ordinary gaining a further point to 77.
Yesterday most of the shares closed flat North Western, North Eastern, and Great Northern deferred dropped 3/4, and South Western Deferred, Midland Deferred, Great Western, and Great Eastern1/2.
Caledonian Preference were a firm point, and finished 3/4 higher and the ordinary were also ½ higher. North British Preference gained 1/4.
The shares of the heavy Hues have given way again to-day. Caledonian Deferred have lost 3/4, to 28 1/2, but the Preference are up 1/2 to 69. North British Orel are also f lower.
Americans.

There has not been very much business done in Americans, which have displayed an irregular tendency. The market both here and in New York appears to be suffering from the reaction following the panic of a month ago, which frightened many investors. Yesterday in Wall Street was one of the dullest days on record, the aggregate sales only amounting to about 300,000 shares, largely confined to about four stocks.
The changes on balance are insignificant, prices being in the main from one to two dollars lower than last Saturday's close.
The market has been idle to-day. Unions have advanced 1 to 141, and there are other gains of 1/4-3/4. Illinois Central have shed 2 to 148.
Egyptians.

For the reasons mentioned in our article last week the market has taken the resignation of Lord Cromer very calmly, and this is a good sign of the confidence which dealers in this section feel that the choice of Sir Eldon Gorst for the position of Consul-General is a guarantee that the high traditions and the wise policy formulated and so ably carried out by Lord Cromer will be continued. It is fully recognised that the valuable experience of Egyptian affairs obtained by Sir Eldon Gorst during his long residence at Cairo, combined with his previous training and his natural abilities, has admirably fitted him to guide the future destinies of Egypt

At the beginning, as was natural, the market was slightly easier, but has since finned up, though there is not much business doing. National Bank of Egypt at on time fell to 24} ex dividend, but are now up to 24|-|. Agricultural Bank have changed hands at 8\ closing 8 5/8-7/8. The Preference are 9 3/8-5/8, and the 3 % Debentures are very nominal at 86-8. Anglo-Egyptian Bank are a wonderfully firm market at 14 1/8-3/8.

Daira Sanieh were at one time as low as 15 1/4, but yesterday they jumped up to 15 3/4, and closed rather sellers at this price. To-day they leave off at 15 3/8- 5/8. The Egyptian Delta Light Railway Preference have been depressed on forced sales, and have been down to 10 5/8, but close to 10 5/8-7/8. Delta Land and Investment have been flat without any recovery, the price falling from 3 1/2 to 2 15/16. They are now 2 7/8- 3 1/8. Union Fonciere are quoted 5 1/4-3/4, and Land Bank of Egypt 8 ¼ -3/4|.
Yesterday Egyptian Estates were offered down to 1 3/4, and the Deferred were 15-18. This morning the ordinary were better at 1 3/4-7/5, and leave off to-night at this price. Corporation of
Western Egypt are unchanged at 5/8 – 7/8, as are also Egyptian Markets at 1 1/4, and Salt & Soda at l /32. Daira Deferred are on offer at 88 without response.
This morning Egyptian Options broke very badly, the shares falling to a nominal price of 10/-s. without any purchasers being found. They close at 3/8-5/8.
Mining.

There appears to be absolutely no interest taken in mining shares, and the market continues to droop for lack of support. There is little probability that this section will receive much attention until the political situation in South Africa is more settled, and the native labour question is disposed of once for all. Investors have dropped so much over mining shares in general, that they are very chary of having anything further to do with them while affairs are in such a state of uncertainty.

This week little business has been done, and the alterations in quotations are slight. Rand Mines leave off tonight at 6 J as compared with 6,27/32 last Saturday, and East Rands at 4 A as against 4,17/32.
Egyptian mining shares are quite lifeless, and no changes have taken place in quotations since last we wrote.

div.head: Walker & Meimarachi, Limited. Sixth Ordinary Dividend of Five per Cent
div.p: Notice is hereby given to holders of Warrants to Bearer for Ordinary Shares of the new Issue that Interest Coupon No. 4 is now payable. The amount is calculated at the rate of 6% per annum to the 30th April 1906 from the dates on which the instalments became payable according to the prospectus.

Coupons must be left at the London Office of the Company, 65 London Wall, E.C., for examination four clear days previous to payment and must be entered in numerical order upon list* which may be obtained on application to the Head Office in London. Foreign and Provincial holders must forward coupons through their Bankers for collection, as they will not be paid through the post
By Order of the Board,

div.head: General Administration of Wakfs. NOTICE.
div.p: Offers will be received at the office of the Wakfs' Delegation at Ghizeh, situated on the west of the Pont des Anglais, on the 9th day of May 1907 from 9 a.m. to midday and from 2 to 4 p.m. for the sale by public auction of one feddan, nine kirata, and twelve sahms situated at Ghizeh, at hod Chagaret Gaddonah. This land is about 280 metres distant from the north of the Pyramid embankment and about 15 metres west of the railway line to Upper Egypt.
The upset price of the said land in block is already fixed at L E. 2,256.

Applicants must either call personally or by proxy at the said office on the day and at the times designated above to inform themselves of the conditions of contract for this deal and afterwards make their offer.
All offers must be accompanied by a guarantee amount to 20% of the sum of the said upset price.
Offers made after stated date and times or not accepted by the guarantee stipulated will not be accepted. 30120-2-1

div.head: THE NILE VALLEY (NEW) COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above- named Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., on Monday, the 6th day of May 1907, at 12 o'clock noon, for the purpose of considering, And if thought fit passing, the subjoined Resolutions.1
RESOLUTIONS.

list.item: "That the capital of the Company be increased to £262,500, by the creation of 250,000 additional shares of ls. each."

"That 218,264 of such additional shares be offered in the first instance at a premium of 0d. per share to the Members of the Company, in the proportion of one new share for every existing share held by them respectively, payable 3d. on application, 6d. on allotment (being the premium) and the balance when required on not less than fourteen days' notice, upon condition that such often be made by notice specifying the number of shares to which the Member is entitled, and limiting the time within which the offer, if not accepted by payment of the amount due on application, shall be deemed to be declined, and with a right to Shareholders to apply at a premium of 6d per share, for the excess shares and any shares not taken by Shareholders entitled to Apply for the same."

'That the Directors be, and are hereby,empowered and authorised to dispose of the shares not taken in response to such offer in such manner, at such prices, at such times and generally upon such terms and conditions as the Directors may in their discretion think fit."

"That Clauses 130 and 158 of the Articles of Association be cancelled and that the following Clause be substituted, viz. :— 130. All shares of the Company for the time being issued, shall rank alike for dividend and in a distribution of assets on a winding up, notwithstanding any difference in the nominal amounts of any of such shares or in the amounts paid up thereon."

div.p: Should the Resolutions be passed by the required majority, they will be submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions at a Second Extraordinary General Meeting, which will be subsequently convened for that purpose.
Dated the 25th day of April, 1907.
By order of the Board,
C. F. Palmer, 10114-1. Secretary.
